data.title: National Geographic History magazine
data.meta_description: Take a look inside this month's NGM
data.text:
|Jesse James: Man and Myth

In the dozen years between 1869 to 1881, Jesse James, his brother Frank, and their brothers in crime became the most wanted, the most despised, and the most celebrated outlaws in the nation. Jesse may have taken part in as many as 19 robberies – banks, trains, and stagecoaches – from Mississippi to West Virginia to Minnesota. But long before the mythic Jesse of song, dime novels, and films, there was a blue-eyed farm boy, son of a Baptist minister and a devoted mother, coming of age during the Civil War.

|The Ancient Roots of Indo-European Languages

Scholars have a long history of searching for the time and place when one mother language was spoken by all living people. They continue the search for the earliest languages spoken by ancient people, in the hopes of finding a common mother tongue. While academics debate the existence and spread of a single unifying language, it is known that many languages today come from the Indo-European group of languages. Around the world today, there are roughly 440 living languages that descend from Indo-European, and the similarities between terms and concepts can be striking. Subscribe now ›

|The Reinvention of Robin Hood

Just as capturing Robin Hood frustrates the sheriff of Nottingham, pinning down the origins of a folk hero challenges scholars tracing his lineage. Stealing from the rich and giving to the poor, Robin Hood and his Merry Men are a permanent part of popular culture. Historian and archivist Joseph Hunter discovered that many different Robin Hoods dotted the history of medieval England, often with variant spellings – and variant personages. Who was the real Robin Hood? Subscribe now ›
